AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Mordecai Richler's Most Ambitious Work
DOC.TEXT: Mordecai Richler has a standard answer ready for those who wonder about the apparent similarities between the fictional Gursky family in his new novel and a certain real-life Canadian dynasty that soared to wealth and prominence in the whiskey business. ``My reply will be that I wouldn't want five years' work reduced to the level of prurient gossip,'' he says. Indeed, Richler closes the lively new book, ``Solomon Gursky Was Here,'' with an author's note that simply states: ``I made the Gurskys up out of my own head.'' The Montreal-based writer is frequently repeating his answer on the promotional tour that is helping to make the novel, his first since ``Joshua Then and Now'' in 1980, one of the big books of the Canadian fall publishing season. It will appear next spring in the United States and a short while later in Britain. ``I think there are two or three superficial resemblances in their early careers, but it's not about that family at all,'' Richler, 58, said of the Bronfman family, who built Seagram's into the world's largest distilling company. He noted that the novel not only includes those ``superficial resemblances'' to the Bronfmans in Montreal but also ranges over Canadian territory from the Prairies to the Arctic and covers subjects from anti-Semitism to the search for the Northwest Passage. ``You write a novel, and it's very difficult to follow it around with explanations,'' Richler said. ``I feel I've had my say.'' The atmosphere of Montreal's prominent Jewish community has served Richler well in his past novels, such as ``The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz'' and ``St. Urbain's Horsemen.'' ``It's certainly the most complex novel I've ever attempted,'' Richler said of his new work. He was interviewed, looking slightly rumpled and smoking small Dutch cigars, at breakfast during his visit to Toronto for an authors' festival. ``It's his longest novel yet, and by far his most ambitious and imaginative,'' reviewer William French wrote in Toronto's Globe and Mail newspaper. ``Whether it's his most satisfying is open to debate.'' Richler works regularly as a journalist and is one of the Canadian writers turned to frequently by foreign publications seeking a home-grown view of the country. He has been working lately on an article about the English-French language tensions in Quebec. The province's English minority lives for the most part in Montreal, the largest city in Quebec. ``It's a quarrel more appropriate to a schoolyard. Whichever side you're on, it's somewhat embarrassing to be quarreling about signs,'' Richler said. Quebec provincial laws restrict the language on all outdoor commercial signs to French. ``It's a very wasting tribal quarrel. It has little to do with the real problems of the country,'' he said. During the hard-fought 1988 campaign over whether Canada should go ahead with a free-trade agreement with the United States, he lined up not with such writing heavyweights as Robertson Davies and Margaret Atwood against the pact but with a lesser known group supporting it. ``I just felt that it was a trade deal,'' Richler said. ``I hope it will work out well. The test will be if it creates more jobs.'' The opponents of the pact, which took effect last Jan. 1, argued that Canadian culture could be overwhelmed if trade barriers were lowered with the United States. ``I thought there was a certain amount of hysteria,'' Richler said. ``I don't think the free trade deal is going to destroy the CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corp.) or Canadian publishing; if I thought so, I would be against it.'' Richler sees an ironic touch to his having taken positions that made him anathema to hard-core Canadian nationalists and his now having written ``a resoundingly Canadian novel.'' He said his publishers seem to believe the material will be considered exotic elsewhere and not be harmed by readers' lack of knowledge about Canada. ``They think it's a very commercial novel,'' he said. Richler lived in Europe, mostly in London, for two decades, returning to his native Montreal in 1972. He also has worked as a screenwriter, including the screenplay for ``The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz,'' and written two well-received children's books.
